ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Learned a LOT more characters and grammar structures, also learned a bit of chinese history/culture
Developed skills in Chinese vocabulary, grammar and speaking.
I improved my Chinese speaking, reading, and writing skills and learned more formal grammar structures.
CHNS HL3 helped me to quickly develop writing, reading, and speaking proficiency.

Interacting with other classmates in group projects, participating in class, lots of class presentations, Chinese reading, writing, speaking, and listening skills. Lots of interesting cultural learning too.

How to conceptualize the process of learning a new language. Chen Laoshi worked to break down much of the ambiguity in the process of learning a new language, even with familiarity as heritage students, and she set up many of us to excel in the course.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Classes were very engaging and the small class size helped with this, course work was heavy but necessary still for solidifying the content

I liked the asynchronous days and final video project too

The exams progressively got harder, with more characters and grammar structures to know, but the partial credit given was very generous, so it was hard to fail a test
Heavy engagement and involvement, but at a pace that at times could seem somewhat intense.

Strengths: I liked the structure of the course, and I learned a lot. I liked that the schedule was planned out beforehand so we always knew what to expect in class.
Weaknesses: none
It's just a totally great course in general. The volume of work is high and not for the faint of heart, but the difficulty of the work itself is not that difficult.
I like the pace of this course. I feels just rigorous enough. I do wish there was more of a focus on improving speaking.

I love how the class is a smaller seminar style because I think its very conducive to participation and learning, especially for a foreign language. Not really any weaknesses, set up well for success and actual learning and practice of language skills.

Strengths: Very structured, clear, and straightforward. The exams were more thoughtful than in prior years, and the material was challenging. Weaknesses: It would be helpful to have a stronger sense of progression, as well as built in review.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, I would definitely recommend! The instructor was very nice and engaging and the grading was generous to the point where you could focus more on learning the content than fixating on the grade.

Due to the time commitment required, Im not sure that I would recommend this unless you are taking this as a requirement or else are fairly devoted to studying Chinese. Certainly a very doable class, however.
yes, speaking chinese regularly is a surefire way to improve, and the heritage classes heavily encourage speaking only in chinese
Yes, I would recommend this course to another heritage student looking to fulfill a language requirement or earn a certificate in Chinese.

I would! The Chinese Department at Yale is just excellent. The professors are extremely kind, and there is a reason for all the work done. The grading is generous, and it was a really enjoyable seminar experience. It's a little tiring because the volume of work, weekly tutorials, and everyday classes add up as the semester goes on, but the work is very predictable--some preparation on the weekends and time management will aid you in doing very well without feeling burned out.
Yes!

Yes I would, although the workload can be a bit heavy, the class is definitely worth it and was my favorite this semester. The smaller class size really helped to make new friends and get good feedback to improve and build confidence and important language skills.

Yes, absolutely. Chen Laoshi is by far one of the most thoughtful and hardworking instructors that I've had at Yale. So long as you stay on top of learning the incoming material, and check in with Chen Laoshi periodically, you can do very well!
